descript.abstract: The Environmental Data Registry (EDR) is a comprehensive, authoritative source of reference information about the definition, source, and uses of environmental data. The EDR catalogs the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) major data collections and helps locate environmental information of interest. As the major tool supporting the Agency's data standards program, the EDR records and disseminates information about Agency data standards and the standard-setting process. The vision for EPA's data standards program is to promote the efficient sharing of environmental information among EPA, states, tribes, and other parties through the cooperative development of data standards. The EDR serves this program in two important ways. First, as a reference tool, the EDR catalogs EPA's information resources and provides information for interpreting the environmental data. The EDR does not contain the environmental data itself, but rather information that describes the data to make it more meaningful. The Environmental Data Registry (EDR) is a comprehensive, authoritative reference for information about the definition, source, and uses of environmental data. It does not contain data, rather offers tools to help use environmental data. XML tag search allows the user to find XML tags for the data elements included in EPA data standards. Code Sets contain permissible values, value meaning names, and value meaning definitions that can be used in applications. The Code Sets have values associated with EPA Data Standards, with national/international standards, or contain lists of values commonly used by EPA programs. The EDR Compare tool allows you to search for and compare data elements from various sources (e.g., data standards). The information resource search allows the user to find application system metadata.
descript.purpose: The purpose of the Environmental Data Registry is to provide a comprehensive reference for information about the definition, source, and uses of environmental data.
descript.supplinf: Information listed here was obtained from http://www.epa.gov/edr/. (previous geoform was 'Database')

idinfo.accconst: No access constraints. The EDR is available to anyone interested in environmental information, including the public, environmental decision makers, industry, researchers, regulated entities, state and local environmental agencies, regulation writers, and computer system developers and managers.

cntperp.cntorg: United States Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Environmental Information

dataqual.complete: The EDR is a comprehensive, authoritative source of reference information.

method.methdesc: The EDR serves to document the diversity of data representations across information systems through central storage of application metadata. This information can be used to support initiatives to identify duplication of data, streamline information collection, and achieve information consistency and sharing across the programs. Second, as the repository for standard data elements, the EDR fosters the use of consistently defined and formatted data elements and sets of data values. These standard data elements and values can be downloaded for use in application system design and reengineering. This capability supports initiatives to achieve enterprise information consistency through standard information representation. The data can also be accessed using the Environmental Data Registry (EDR) Portal, a search engine that enables users to search metadata registry content using a URL with integrated search capabilities. It enables users to search and seamlessly navigate to detail pages meeting the search criteria. An EDR Portal Substance Search has been developed so system developers can build URLs that automatically query various substance data and display the appropriate detail information from three EPA applications: Substance Registry System (SRS), Chemical Registry System (CRS), and the Biology Registry System (BioRS).

procstep.procdesc: The EDR has been redesigned to be part of a single metadata registry, a reference to EPA information resources. The new system design integrates several collections of EPA metadata, including data elements, chemical identification information, biological taxonomy information, and terms with definitions. The integrated information is accessed by several EPA applications including the Environmental Data Registry (EDR), the Substance Registry System (SRS), the Chemical Registry System (CRS), the Biology Registry System (BioRS), and the Terminology Reference System (TRS). This integration supports Agency information integration activities and helps make Agency metadata information more meaningful.

overview.eaover: Entity - Enviromental Information; Attributes - data standards, newsletter, compare tool, XML, code set, search tool, registration, and subscription.

cntperp.cntorg: United States Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Environmental Information

distinfo.distliab: The EDR contains metadata from EPA and stakeholder sources. All information in the EDR is displayed as received from the source. Although the Office of Environmental Information (OEI) accepts no responsibility for the data's quality, it provides this information to document the depth and breadth of Agency-related information. The EDR has no statutory or regulatory standing. While EPA applied its best efforts to include complete and accurate information in the EDR, EPA cannot be held responsible for errors or omissions and is not liable for any direct, indirect, or consequential damages resulting from using this information. Reliance on the information contained in these systems by any party cannot be used as a defense in any administrative or judicial proceeding. In such proceedings, the specific language of the relevant regulation or statute is binding. GEMET Copyright The EDR contains the European Environment Agency (EEA), European Topic Centre on Catalogue of Data Sources (ETC/CDS), General Multilingual Environmental Thesaurus (GEMET). The EEA owns the copyright of GEMET. Although GEMET is owned by the EEA, the Agency distributes it free to interested users. The ETC/CDS maintains the EEA master file from which copies are produced. The EEA has no intention of preventing other users from changing it. For example, new users are free to further develop the master copy. However, unless a contractual agreement exists between the EEA and the current master copyholder, the latter cannot claim to be the master file keeper or maintainer. The EEA regards the name GEMET as its own "registered trademark."
